occurrences.line_text: To let faire Florimell in bands remayne,
In bands of loue, and in sad thraldomes chayne;
And now they doe with captiue bands him bind;
His bands, and follow'd him with gladfull glee,
Fast bound on euery side with iron bands,
Bound vnto me, but not with such hard bands
And many yron bands on him to lade.
And farre away, amid their rakehell bands,
Nor bands of nature, that wilde beastes restraine,
Witnesse may Burbon be, whom all the bands,
But they that breake bands of ciuilitie,
He him by all the bands of loue besought,
So hauing all his bands againe vptyde,
Or kept in bands, or from their loues exyled,
These two, vnworthy of your wretched bands;
He from those bands weend him to haue vnwound.
He was vnwares surprisd in subtile bands
subdew, and bynd in bands.
And Bellamour in bands, till that her syre
Straunge bands, whose like till then he neuer bore,
Into like bands, ne maystred any more:
And commen to his reskew, ere his bitter bane.
It neuer rests, till it haue wrought his finall bane.
And feeding on the bayt of his owne bane.
That breathed euer forth a filthie banefull smell.
Or bit them with his banefull teeth of iniury.
And foule defame doe decke thy bloudy baner?
He gan renew the late forbidden banes,
And Bangor with massacred Martyrs fill;
Watching to banish Care their enimy,
To banish cowardize and bastard feare;
striue her to banish cleane.
To banish sloth, that oft doth noble mindes annoy.
To banish feare, and with Sardonian smyle
Against her brought, to banish all remorse,
Desired be, or thence to banish bale:
That naught may boot to banishe them from thence:
O let him far be banished away,
And from her balefull minde all care he banished.
Banisht from liuing wights, our wearie dayes we waste.
Banisht from Princely bowre to wastfull wood:
From all braue knights be banisht with defame:
And into moores and marshes banisht had,
Vpon the banke, yet wilt thy selfe not passe the flood?
Which to behold, he clomb vp to the banke,
Through thicke and thin, both ouer banke and bush
For by no meanes the high banke he could sease,
There where the mouldred earth had cav'd the banke;
Bursting forth teares, like springs out of a banke,
The bankes are ouerflowen, when stopped is the flood.
And Xanthus sandy bankes with bloud all ouerflowne.
And shadie seates, and sundry flowring bankes,
And to her guestes doth bounteous banket dight,
Their banket houses burne, their buildings race,
Which ended, then his bloudy banket should beginne.
Nor bounds nor banks his headlong ruine may sustaine.
And comming forth, shall spred his banner braue
And lastly to despoyle of knightly bannerall.
With scutchins gilt and banners broad displayd:
Ne hostes of men with banners brode dispred,
And with blasphemous bannes high God in peeces tare.
In vaine the Pagan bannes, and sweares, and rayles,
Swearing, and banning most blasphemously,
To that great banquet of the watry Gods,
The manner of the Gods when they at banquet bee.
Great cheare, like one vnto a banquet bid;
The royall banquets, and the rare delights,
Or his baptized hands now greater grew;
Her single person to their barbarous truth,
At sight whereof his barbarous heart was fired,
And goodly gorgeous barbes, him found not theare.
Within the Barbican a Porter sate,
To rest my barcke, which hath bene beaten late
And with his bodie bard the way atwixt them twaine.
All bard with golden bendes, which were entayld
All bard with double bends, that none could weene
Of such deceipt, kept th'yron dore fast bard,
And passage bard to all, that thither came,
His face was couered, and his head was bar'd,
He lent against a tree, that backeward onset bard.
And many Bardes, that to the trembling chord
With wanton Bardes, and Rymers impudent,
Bards tell of many women valorous
That path they take, that beaten seemd most bare,
His feete all bare, his beard all hoarie gray,
For on his backe a heauy load he bare
All bare through peoples feet, which thither traueiled.
And in his hand his Portesse still he bare,
And in his hand a burning hart he bare,
Me silly maid away with him he bare,
That in his armour bare a croslet red.
From top to toe no place appeared bare,
His speare of heben wood behind him bare,
His bare thin cheekes for want of better bits,
Her necke and breasts were euer open bare,
With which bare wretched wights he dayly clad,
Where seeing Mercie, that his steps vp bare,
Yet was their manner then but bare and plaine:
Vnto an aged woman, poore and bare,
But most were stampt, and in their metall bare
Her snowy brest was bare to readie spoyle
Yet in his fall so well him selfe he bare,
That in late yeares so faire a blossome bare,
That all the rest it seem'd they robbed bare
Conceiu'd these infants, and how them she bare,
Vpon her fell all naked bare displayd;
He bare, and by the colours in his crest,
He snatcht from Ida hill, and with him bare:
So furiously they met, that either bare
Shew'd all his bodie bare vnto the cruell dent.
Which of great mother Venus bare the name,
All which the Oceans daughter to him bare
And the first blossome of faire vertue bare,
Whose scalp is bare, that bondage doth bewray,
To whom nought else, but bare life doth remaine,
And eke to th'earth his burden with him bare:
And laught so loud, that all his teeth wide bare
His side all bare and naked ouertooke,
And in his wide great mouth away her bare,
But the bare ground, with hoarie mosse bestrowed,
His shield, his helmet, and his curats bare.
He lyes (said he) vpon the cold bare ground,
Some whet their kniues, and strip their elboes bare:
Gathered together, and them homeward bare:
Arriued in this Isle though bare and blunt,
Do seize vpon some beast, whose flesh is bare,
And bared all his head vnto the bone;
Her bared bosome she doth broad display;
That bare-head knight for dread and dolefull teene,
A Ladie on rough waues, row'd in a sommer barge.
There eke my feeble barke a while may stay,
And to the wished hauen bring thy weary barke.
The little barke vnto the shore to draw,
For the flit barke, obaying to her mind,
In PhÃ¦drias flit barke ouer that perlous shard.
And enuie base, to barke at sleeping fame:
And he eftsoones gan launch his barke forthright.
Wherein my feeble barke is tossed long,
That durst not barke; and rather had he dy,
And all the night the dogs did barke and howle
But after them did barke, and still backbite,
Her weary barke at last vppon mine Isle did rest.
At him began aloud to barke and bay,
At last some fisher barke doth neare behold,
Some were of dogs, that barked day and night,
As when two Barkes, this caried with the tide,
But most that curre barking with bitter sownd,
Barking and biting all that him doe bate,
With which he bayd and loudly barkt at mee,
The third, the goodly Barow, which doth hoord
There was no barre to stop, nor foe him to empeach.
Though false Duessa it to barre
To barre the prease of people farre away;
The Lists were closed fast, to barre the rout
Both which to barre, he with this answere met her;
Then was there brought, as prisoner to the barre,
Vnto the barre, whereas she was arrayned:
She found no meanes to barre him, but to faine
They found the gates fast barred long ere night,
With thornes and barren brakes enuirond round,
The barren ground was full of wicked weedes,
That neither yron barres, nor brasen locke
From the swift Barry, tombling downe apace,
Basciante did him selfe most curteous shew;
Gan choose his dame with Basciomani gay,
And her base Elfin brood there for thee left.
Then fowle reuenging rage, and base contentious iarre.
Such entertainment base, ne ought would eat,
Streight at his foot in base humilitee,
She broke his wanton darts, and quenched base desire.
And to be easd of that base burden still did erne.
And that it was a groome of base degree,
Disguised like that groome of base degree,
To them, that list, these base regardes I lend:
Others through friends, others for base regard;
And enuie base, to barke at sleeping fame:
And twixt them both a quadrate was the base,
In his big base them fitly answered,
With the base murmure of the waters fall:
Not that same, which doth base affections moue
And base attyre, that none might them bewray,
She, that base Braggadochio did affray,
And his base thought with terrour and with aw
And said; Thy offers base I greatly loth,
That both were bent t'auenge his vsage base,
For in base mind nor friendship dwels nor enmity.
Now base and contemptible did appeare,
Regardlesse of that queane so base and vilde,
Which keeper is this Dwarfe, her dearling base,
Could frame in earth, and forme of substance base,
That cropt the branches of the sient base,
In the base blood of such a rascall crew;
And to the boaster said; Thou losell base,
And armes dishonour with base villanie,
That he of womens hands so base a death should dy.
And put to that base seruice of her band,
That they were borne to base humilitie,
And sooth oft seene, that proudest harts base loue hath blynded.
To be so scorned of a base borne thrall,
Which had her Lord in her base prison pent,
The hight, and downe descend vnto the base.
And hearing pleas of people meane and base.
But blotted with condition vile and base,
Yet glad at last to make most base submission,
Borne of the brooding of Echidna base,
For he loathd leasing, and base flattery,
And him to beare, she thought it thing too base.
Me then to be full base and euill borne,
Did scorne the challenge of so base a thrall:
Gan him entreat euen with submission base,
Yet howsoeuer base and meane it were,
And running streight vpon that villaine base,
By such discourteous deeds discouering his base kind.
And him bewayling with affection base,
Though of meane parentage and kindred base,
To follow sheepe, and shepheards base attire:
But being bred vnder base shepheards wings,
The gentle heart scornes base disparagement.
Or a war-monger to be basely nempt;
With so braue badges one so basely borne;
So great her pride, that she such basenesse much abhord.
So seldome seene, that one in basenesse set
That euen the Prince his basenesse did despize,
He for such basenesse shamefully him shent,
He sent to her his basenet, as a faithfull band.
And rising forth out of her baser bowre,
His baser brest, but in his kestrell kind
His lustlesse limbes, and drowne his baser mind,
The baser wit, whose idle thoughts alway
Some baser metall, which commend he will
Made cruell hauocke of the baser crew,
Euen so the baser mind it selfe displayes,
In stead of Curiets and bases fit for fight.
Or else to course about their bases light;
And makes it seruant to her basest part:
The loue and seruice of the basest crew?
Pardon the boldnesse of thy basest thrall,
His countenaunce was bold, and bashed not
The bashfull bloud her snowy cheekes did dye,
Doth first peepe forth with bashfull modestee,
Whereto her bashfull shamefastnesse ywrought
And did his head for bashfulnesse abase,
Like as the Basiliske of serpents seede,
Was drawne forth, and in siluer basin layd,
To banish cowardize and bastard feare;
Thought in his bastard armes her to embrace.
Basted with bends of gold on euery side,
The lether-winged Bat, dayes enimy,
Yet there the steele stayd not, but inly bate
Bate somewhat of that Maiestie and awe,
Barking and biting all that him doe bate,
To bath in bloud of faithlesse enemy;
And th'English Bath, and eke the german Spau,
Might not be purgd with water nor with bath;
And vsd to bath themselues in that deceiptfull shade.
She oft did bath, and oft againe did dry;
And in his costly Bath causd to bee site:
To bath their hands in bloud of dearest freend,
To bath in ioy and amorous desire,
And glisters wide, as als' of wondrous Bath,
And bathe in pleasaunce of the ioyous shade,
Some wrestle, some do run, some bathe in christall flood.
Or bathe him in a fountaine by some couert glade.
And with ambrosiall kisses bathe his eyes;
Bathed in wanton blis and wicked ioy:
Till we be bathed in a liuing well;
Some bathed kisses, and did soft embrew,
And those which therein bathed, mote offend.
Where still he bathed lay in his owne bloody gore.
Does swim, and bathes himselfe in courtly blis,
Behold the boyling Bathes at Cairbadon,
Bathing her selfe in origane and thyme:
Which therein bathing, seemed to contend,
Being through former bathing mollifide,
Redoubted battaile ready to darrayne,
Did to him pace, sad battaile to darrayne,
And him in hardy battaile ouercame,
So readie dight, fierce battaile to assay,
And dreadfull battaile twixt them do darraine:
(Said he) and battailes none are to be fought?
And many bloudie battailes fought in place
Speake they, which haue beheld the battailes, which it wan.
And many battailes fought, and many fraies
And battailes doubtfull proofe their rights to try,
And in three battailes did so deadly daunt,
And vnto battaill bad them selues addresse:
From whence she might behold that battailles proof
In sun-bright armes, and battailous array:
Glistring in armes and battailous aray,
And match his brother proud in battailous array.
Did lay strong siege, and battailous assault,
Of hungry whelpes, his battailous bold brood,
With which he wont to stirre vp battailous alarmes.
Which will her cause in battailous array
Sir Artegall, in battailous array
Against the heauen in order battailous,
Sith late with him I batteil vaine would boste;
Tho when this breathlesse woxe, that batteil gan renew.
Aboue all knights on earth, that batteill vndertake.
And threaten batteill to the Faery knight;
Who likewise gan himselfe to batteill dight,
And well approu'd in batteilous affray,
That from henceforth in batteilous array
The spoiles of Princes hang'd, which were in battel won.
To proue his puissance in battell braue
So both to battell fierce arraunged arre,
Himselfe to battell with his couched speare.
End of the doubtfull battell deemed tho
(A sory sight) arraung'd in battell new,
And oft refreshed, battell oft renue:
And left the doubtfull battell hastily,
Whom when the Prince, to battell new addrest,
Is this the battell, which thou vauntst to fight
And shoke his scales to battell readie drest;
And boystrous battell make, each other to auenge.
So new this new-borne knight to battell new did rise.
And did himselfe to battell readie dight;
Who prickt with courage kene, did cruell battell breath.
And fiercely vnto battell sterne themselues prepar'd.
Thence forth in battell neuer sword to beare,
To battell, if thou meane her loue to gaine:
Withhold your bloudie hands from battell fierce,
Not this rude kind of battell, nor these armes
And vnto battell doe your selues addresse;
And gan themselues prepare to battell greedily.
Where he an end of battell, and of life did make.
Encountred him in battell well ordaind,
Raisd warre, and him in battell ouerthrew:
An army brought, and with him battell fought,
There she with them a cruell battell tride,
But shortly was by Coyll in battell slaine:
Who hauing oft in battell vanquished
And to him brought, fresh battell to renew:
And of the battell balefull end had made,
And gan himselfe to second battell bend,
Aboue all knights, that euer battell tride,
Fierce battell against one, with cruell might and maine.
Both slaine in battell vpon Layburne plaine,
And vsd the same in battell aye to beare;
And vnto battell did her selfe prepaire.
But that he must do battell with the Sea-nymphes sonne.
The bloudie battell, and to stirre vp strife,
Tho gan the battell freshly to begin;
And to the battell doth her selfe prepare:
For she list not the battell to abide,
Or bide him battell without further treat.
Battell against the Gods? so we a God inuade.
Signe of nigh battell, or got victory;
The hurts whereof me now from battell stay,
Yet would not let their battell so be broken,
With all their force, and battell strong to wage
And battell made the dreddest daungerous,
Vpon which ground this same great battell grew,
The battell twixt three brethren, with
Rusht fiercely forth, the battell to renew,
And cruell battell twixt themselues doe make,
Thus did the battell varie to and fro,
As if but then the battell had begonne:
Desirous both to haue the battell donne;
Whom formerly he had in battell wonne,
The battell, offred in so knightly wize.
And had in many a battell oft bene tride,
That none against them battell durst maintaine.
Vnable he new battell to darraine,
As if but now the battell wexed warme.
Her claym'd, by him in battell wonne long sens:
And readie were new battell to darraine.
Whilest thus in battell they embusied were,
Ne thenceforth euer strike in battell stroke,
But foure of them the battell best beseemed,
As if but then the battell had begonne,
And would them faine from battell to surceasse,
To rip vp wrong, that battell once hath tried;
Expert in battell and in deedes of armes;
They rose in armes, and all in battell order stood.
So sharpe a battell, that so many did dismay.
To warne her foe to battell soone be prest:
Was to the battell whilome ready dight.
After that them in battell he had wonne.
The vse of armes, and battell quite forgone:
Kindling a fresh, gan battell to renew,
The proofe of battell, now in doubtfull night,
With that him selfe to battell he did frame;
In bloudy battell for a Ladie deare,
And eke this battels end, will need another place.
All those great battels, which thou boasts to win,
And write the battels of his great godhed:
He fought great battels with his saluage fone;
And with great honour many battels try:
Where be the battels, where the shield and speare,
And cruell battels, which he whilome fought
He gan to faint, toward the battels end,
And sundry battels, which she hath atchieued
That battels vtmost triall to aduenter.
Fought many battels without wound or losse;
And in all battels bore away the baies.
And fowly battered his comely corse,
That bloudie scutchin being battered sore,
And subtile engines bet from batteree,
All those against that fort did bend their batteries.
With which they dayly made most dreadfull battery.
Rather for pleasure, then for battery or fight.
And with huge strokes, and cruell battery
But that continuall battery will riue,
For sleepe they sayd would make her battill better.
Beaten with stones downe from the battilment,
Vnto the battilment to be vpbrought,
That from the battlements she ready seem'd to fall.
And with his yron batton, which he bore,
Deepe dinted furrowes in the battred mayle;
And him to dust thought to haue battred quight,
They battred day and night, and entraunce did awate.
And bowd his battred visour to his brest:
His battred ballances in peeces lay,
That they his shield in peeces battred haue,
And brusht, and battred them without remorse,
But will at last be wonne with battrie long,
As three great Culuerings for battrie bent,
Which battring, downe it on the church doth glance,
Strong warres they make, and cruell battry bend
Whom foe with double battry doth assaile,
And that fourth band, which cruell battry bent,
To hurt good knights, was as it were her baude,
The heauens bright-shining baudricke to enchace;
Athwart his brest a bauldrick braue he ware,
Well as she might, and with braue bauldrick garnished.
Knit with a golden bauldricke, which forelay
The wakefull dogs did neuer cease to bay,
And calmy bay, on th'one side sheltered
Like dastard Curres, that hauing at a bay
That at the length vnto a bay he brought her,
Vnto his bay, and captiued her thought.
At him began aloud to barke and bay,
Into this bay of perill and disgrace?
Like a wylde Bull, that being at a bay,
Like as a Mastiffe hauing at a bay
Yet making many a borde, and many a bay,
With which he bayd and loudly barkt at mee,
He feedes vpon the cooling shade, and bayes
And their proud girlonds of tryumphant bayes
To win a willow bough, whilest other weares the bayes.
A Baylieffe errant forth in post did passe,
And falsed oft his blowes, t'illude him with such bayt.
In frayle intemperance through sinfull bayt;
As saluage Bull, whom two fierce mastiues bayt,
Through foolish pitty, then her guilefull bayt
Ne euer shruncke, ne euer sought to bayt
She feeling him thus bite vpon the bayt,
And feeding on the bayt of his owne bane.
For well he weened, that so glorious bayte
Gan forth to lay his bayte her to beguyle,
Vnder blake stole hyding her bayted hooke,
He courted her, yet bayted euery word,
Is bayted of a mastiffe, and a hound,
With pleasures poisoned baytes.
Vnto thy bounteous baytes, and pleasing charmes,
Whose luring baytes oftimes doe heedlesse harts entyse.
Another while I baytes and nets display,
That makes them doubt, their wits be not their owne:
Be well aware, quoth then that Ladie milde,
The youthfull knight could not for ought be staide,
Add faith vnto your force, and be not faint:
Well worthy be you of that Armorie,
Ye all forwearied be: for what so strong,
Might there be heard: but carelesse Quiet lyes,
To be the chastest flowre, that ay did spring
Saint George himself ye would haue deemed him to be.
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
To be the fairest wight, that liued yit;
Did yield her comely person, to be at my call.
So hard the discord was to be agreede.
O leaue her soone, or let her soone be slaine.
Till we be bathed in a liuing well;
That from the bloud he might be innocent,
Farre be it from your thought, and fro my will,
Where noblest knights were to be found on earth:
To looken backe; his eyes be fixt before.
Deare Sir, what euer that thou be in place:
To be partaker of her wandring woe,
That made her selfe a Queene, and crownd to be,
Not meet to be of counsell to a king,
Ne would his looser life be tide to law,
Vpon a Lion, loth for to be led;
So be, O Queene, you equall fauour showe.
To be aueng'd each on his enimy.
Be vnreueng'd, that calles to you aboue
Thereto said he, Faire Dame be nought dismaid
Ne yet of present perill be affraid;
Where euer yet I be, my secrete aid
O what of Gods then boots it to be borne,
Or else goe them auenge, and let be seene,
So well they sped, that they be come at length
And handle softly, till they can be healed:
Till they be come vnto the furthest part:
Great paines, & greater praise, both neuer to be donne.
A ruefull sight, as could be seene with eie;
And would as Ammons sonne be magnifide,
That of no enuious eyes he mote be spyde:
Desird of forreine foemen to be knowne,
Too late it was, to Satyres to be told,
